p: At the end of the 2 months obesity-induction period (NFD vs. HFD), the HFD group was randomly sorted into two subsets: HFD ( n = 24) or HFD+GbE ( n = 27). For the two following weeks, both HFD and HFD+GbE groups showed reduced food intake in comparison to NFD (45.1 and 50.1%, respectively; p < 0.001), but the HFD+GbE group showed reduced food intake in comparison to HFD (8.9%, p = 0.014). The energy intake was statistically similar between NFD and HFD; however, the HFD+GbE energy intake was significantly lower than NFD (8.7%, p = 0.001) and HFD (8.9%, p < 0.001) ( Figures 3A,B). Body weight gain (g) and food efficiency [BW gain (g)/ food ingestion (g)] during the 2 weeks supplementation period were monitored; however, no statistically significant differences were found ( Figures 4A,B).
